subsubsection.title: The Definition

definition.title: Continuity
definition.p: A function is continuous at input a if \ds \lim_{x\to a} f(x) = f(a)
If this condition fails, then f is said to be discontinuous at input a.
f is continuous on an interval if it is continuous at every number in the interval.

assemblage.title: Conditions for Continuity
assemblage.p:
Continuity of a function requires three things:
a is in the domain of f
\ds \lim_{x\to a} f(x) exists
\ds \lim_{x\to a} f(x) = f(a)

assemblage.title: Types of Discontinuities
assemblage.p:
There are three kinds of discontinuities which we will encounter:
Vertical Asymptote
Jump Discontinuity
Removable Discontinuity

example.statement: Sketch an example of each of the three kinds of discontinuities.

subsubsection.definition: Continuity from the Right and Left Continuity (Right and Left) A function f is said to be continuous from the right at input a if \ds \lim_{x\to a^+} f(x) = f(a), and f is continuous from the left at input a if \ds \lim_{x\to a^-} f(x) = f(a).

theorem.title: Properties of Continuous Functions
theorem.statement:
If f and g are continuous at a, and if c is a constant, then the following functions are all continuous at a:
f\pm g
cf
fg
\dfrac{f}{g}, for g\neq 0
f\circ g

example.statement: Prove the first property of continuous functions.

question.statement: Can you prove the remaining 4 properties?

theorem.title: Types of Continuous Functions
theorem.statement:
The following functions are continuous on their domain:
Polynomials
Rational Functions
Root Functions
Trigonometric Functions

subsubsection.title: The Intermediate Value Theorem

theorem.title: Intermediate Value Theorem
theorem.p: Suppose that f is continuous on the closed interval [a,b], and let N be any number between f(a) and f(b), where f(a)\neq f(b). Then, there exists a number c in (a,b) such that f(c) = N.
